title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: U-statistic order 2 form: Un=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Xj)U_n = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, X_j) hh symmetric kernel function, X1,…,XnX_1, \dots, X_n potentially dependent observations.

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: decoupling principle replaces dependent pairs (Xi,Xj)(X_i, X_j) independent pairs (Xi,Yj)(X_i, Y_j) YjY_j independent copies XjX_j. decoupled version becomes: Un′=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Yj)U_n' = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, Y_j) appropriate conditions, UnU_n Un′U_n' similar asymptotic properties, Un′U_n' much easier analyze involves independent terms .

code: cosine_similarity <- function(x, y) {   dot_product <- sum(x * y)   norm_x <- sqrt(sum(x^2))   norm_y <- sqrt(sum(y^2))   dot_product / (norm_x * norm_y) }  # Use it cosine_kernel <- create_kernel(cosine_similarity, "Cosine Similarity") cosine_result <- decouple_u_stat(data_numeric, cosine_kernel, B = 200, seed = 123) plot(cosine_result, main = "Cosine Similarity Analysis")

code: # A distance kernel that weights the first half of the vector more heavily weighted_distance <- function(x, y, weights = NULL) {   if (is.null(weights)) {     n <- length(x)     weights <- c(rep(2, n/2), rep(1, n - n/2))  # First half double weight   }   sqrt(sum(weights * (x - y)^2)) }  # Use it weighted_kernel <- create_kernel(weighted_distance, "Weighted Distance") weighted_result <- decouple_u_stat(data_numeric, weighted_kernel, B = 200, seed = 123) plot(weighted_result, main = "Weighted Distance Analysis")

title: Getting Started with UStatDecouple
text: kernel needs additional parameters, create wrapper function:
code: # A kernel with a customizable parameter custom_distance <- function(alpha = 1) {   function(x, y) {     (sum(abs(x - y)^alpha))^(1/alpha)   } }  # Create kernel with alpha = 2 (Euclidean-like) euclidean_like <- create_kernel(custom_distance(alpha = 2), "Minkowski (α=2)") result1 <- decouple_u_stat(data_numeric, euclidean_like, B = 200, seed = 123)  # Create kernel with alpha = 1 (Manhattan-like) manhattan_like <- create_kernel(custom_distance(alpha = 1), "Minkowski (α=1)") result2 <- decouple_u_stat(data_numeric, manhattan_like, B = 200, seed = 123)  # Compare cat(sprintf("α=2 p-value: %.4f\n", result1@p_value)) #> α=2 p-value: 0.1995 cat(sprintf("α=1 p-value: %.4f\n", result2@p_value)) #> α=1 p-value: 0.1995

title: Getting Started with UStatDecouple
text: p-value calculated using two-tailed test based decoupled distribution: Interpretation: p < 0.05: Strong evidence dependence p < 0.01: strong evidence dependence p < 0.001: Extremely strong evidence dependence p ≥ 0.05: significant evidence dependence
code: # The p-value calculation null_mean <- mean(result@decoupled_distribution) null_sd <- sd(result@decoupled_distribution) z_score <- (result@original_stat - null_mean) / null_sd p_value <- 2 * (1 - pnorm(abs(z_score)))  cat(sprintf("Z-score: %.4f\n", z_score)) #> Z-score: 1.3561 cat(sprintf("P-value: %.4f\n", p_value)) #> P-value: 0.1751

title: Real-World Data Analysis with UStatDecouple
text: ’ll create kernel measures similarity genes based genomic context.
code: # Custom kernel: measures similarity based on chromosomal proximity proximity_kernel <- function(gr1, gr2) {   # Extract chromosome and positions   chr1 <- as.character(seqnames(gr1))   chr2 <- as.character(seqnames(gr2))      start1 <- start(gr1)   end1 <- end(gr1)   start2 <- start(gr2)   end2 <- end(gr2)      # Calculate similarity score   if (chr1 == chr2) {     # Same chromosome: similarity decreases with distance     midpoint1 <- (start1 + end1) / 2     midpoint2 <- (start2 + end2) / 2     distance <- abs(midpoint1 - midpoint2)          # Normalized similarity (1 - distance / chromosome_length)     # Using a large constant for normalization     similarity <- exp(-distance / 1e6)  # Exponential decay   } else {     # Different chromosomes: lower similarity     similarity <- 0.1   }      return(similarity) }  # Convert to list format gene_list <- lapply(1:length(selected_genes), function(i) {   selected_genes[i] }) names(gene_list) <- paste0("Gene_", 1:length(gene_list))

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: UStatDecouple implements probabilistic decoupling techniques U-statistics, transforming dependent sample statistics averages independent sequences. package provides rigorous statistical tools genomic data analysis, enabling accurate variance estimation, hypothesis testing, confidence interval construction complex genomic metrics. package based theoretical framework developed de la Peña colleagues decoupling inequalities probability theory , specifically optimized biological sequence analysis genomic applications. framework realized S4 object-oriented design high-performance C++ (Rcpp) back-end implementation, addressing quadratic (O(n2)O(n^2)) complexity U-statistics. Parallel processing supported via BiocParallel, pre-defined biological kernels facilitate DNA sequence gene expression analyses. Vignettes case studies illustrating provide package practical applications methods.

text: package implements Friedman-de la Peña decoupling method, transforms dependent U-statistics: Un=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Xj)U_n = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, X_j) independent versions: Un′=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Yj)U_n' = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, Y_j) YjY_j independent copies XjX_j. transformation enables use classical statistical methods designed independent data .
